    <dl>
           <dt>ra 1</dt>
           <dd><em>ra</em> the 2nd semivowel (corresponding to the vowels <em>&#x1e5b;</em> and <em>&#x1e5d;</em>, and having the sound of <em>r</em> in <em>ring</em>)</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; rak&#x0101;ra </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;k&#x0101;ra</em> m. the letter or sound <em>ra</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x25cb;r&#x00e2;di-r&#x0101;ma-sahasra-n&#x0101;man</em> n. N. of a collection of the thousand names of R&#x0101;ma (from the Brahmay&#x0101;mala)</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; rapraty&#x0101;h&#x0101;ra </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;praty&#x0101;h&#x0101;ra</em> m. N. of a partic. Praty&#x0101;h&#x0101;ra (q.v.) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-kha&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;ana</em> n. <em>-ma&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;ana</em> n. <em>-var&#x1e47;ana</em> n. N. of wks</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; rodara </dt>
           <dd><em>r&#x00f4;dara</em> m. 'containing an <em>r</em>', N. of the Cakra-v&#x0101;ka (q.v.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#V&#x0101;m">V&#x0101;m.</a> v, 1, 15 (v. l.)</dd>

           <dt>ra 2</dt>
           <dd><em>ra</em> (in prosody) a cretic (- ? -) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pi&#x1e45;g">Pi&#x1e45;g.</a></dd>

           <dd><em>ra</em> mfn. (&#x221a;<em>r&#x0101;</em>) acquiring, possessing <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Naish">Naish.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; giving, effecting <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;i&#x015b;">&#x015a;i&#x015b;.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; speed </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x0101;</em>), f. (only <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a>) amorous play (= <em>vibhrama</em>) <font color="#FF0000" font size=-2><a name="p859-3"></a>[Page 859, Column 3]</font> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; giving </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; gold </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x012b;</em>), f. going, motion <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; n. brightness, splendour (used in explaining an etymology) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a></dd>

   <dt>ra&#x1e43;su </dt>

           <dt>ra&#x1e43;h </dt>
           <dd><em>ra&#x1e43;h</em> (for <em>ra&#x1e45;gh</em>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x221a;">&#x221a;.</a><em>la&#x1e45;gh</em> and <em>raghu</em>, <em>laghu</em>, cl. 1. P.            <dd>&#x2022; (in <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> and <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> also <em>rak&#x1e63;&#x00e1;s</em>, m.) an evil being or demon, a R&#x0101;kshasa (q.v </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; in <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VP">VP.</a> identified with Nir&#x1e5b;iti or Nair&#x1e5b;ita) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; pl. N. of a warlike race, g. <em>par&#x015b;v-&#x0101;di</em></dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; rak&#x1e63;astva </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;tv&#x00e1;</em> n. the nature of a R&#x0101;kshasa, fiendishness, malice <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a></dd>

   <dd><em>rak&#x1e63;asy&#x00e1;</em> mf(<em>&#x0101;</em>)n. useful for (keeping off) R&#x0101;kshasas, anti-demoniacal <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#TS">TS.</a> (cf. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 4-4, 121)</dd>

  <dd>&#x2022; ashes (used as a preservative) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
  <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x0101;</em> or <em>&#x012b;</em>), f. a piece of thread or silk bound round the wrist on partic. occasions (esp. on the full moon of &#x015a;r&#x0101;va&#x1e47;a, either as an amulet and preservative against misfortune, or as a symbol of mutual dependence, or as a mark of respect) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MW">MW.</a></dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; (with <em>br&#x0101;hma</em>) N. of the author of <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> x, 162 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Anukr">Anukr.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>ghn&#x012b;</em>), f. Acorus Calamus <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a></dd>

   <dt>&#x226b; rak&#x1e63;&#x1e47;a </dt>
   <dd><em>rak&#x1e63;&#x1e47;a</em> m. (cf. P&#x0101;&#x1e47;. 3-3, 90) protection, guard (<em>&#x25cb;&#x1e47;am-&#x221a;k&#x1e5b;</em>, with abl. 'to protect from') <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Bha&#x1e6d;&#x1e6d;">Bha&#x1e6d;&#x1e6d;.</a></dd>

           <dd><em>ragh</em> v. l. for &#x221a;<em>rak</em>, q.v</dd>

           <dt>raghu </dt>
           <dd><em>ragh&#x00fa;</em> mf(<em>vii&#x0341;</em>)n. (&#x221a;<em>ra&#x1e43;h</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; cf. <em>laghu</em>) hastening, going speedily, fleet, rapid <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; light, fickle <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; m. a racer, fleet courser <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of an ancient king and ancestor of R&#x0101;ma (described in Raghu-va&#x1e43;&#x015b;a as son of Dil&#x012b;pa and Su-dakshi&#x1e47;&#x0101; </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; he was father of Aja who was father of Da&#x015b;a-ratha </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; hence he was great-grandfather of R&#x0101;ma </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; in the R&#x0101;m&#x0101;ya&#x1e47;a Raghu is said to be son of Kakutstha </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; in the Hari-va&#x1e43;&#x015b;a two Raghus are mentioned among the ancestors of R&#x0101;ma) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hariv">Hariv.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Ragh">Ragh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pur">Pur.</a> (cf. IW. 344) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of a son of Gautama Buddha <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Buddh">Buddh.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of various authors (also with <em>daiva-j&#x00f1;a</em> and <em>s&#x016b;ri</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Cat">Cat.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; = the poem <em>raghu-va&#x1e43;&#x015b;a</em> (cf. next) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; pl. the descendants of Raghu <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Ragh">Ragh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R&#x0101;jat">R&#x0101;jat.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; raghuk&#x0101;ra </dt>

           <dt>ra&#x00f1;j </dt>
           <dd><em>ra&#x00f1;j</em> or <em>raj</em>, cl. 1. 4. P. &#x0100;. (cf. Dh&#x0101;tup. xxiii, 30 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; xxvi, 58) <em>rajati</em>, <em>&#x25cb;te</em> (only Gr </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-ra&#x00f1;jati</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> vii, 99, 11) or <em>rajyati</em>, <em>&#x25cb;te</em> (Gr. also pf. P. <em>rara&#x00f1;ja</em>, 3rd du. <em>rarajatu&#x1e25;</em> or <em>rara&#x00f1;jatu&#x1e25;</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; &#x0100;. <em>rara&#x00f1;je</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; aor. <em>ar&#x0101;&#x1e45;k&#x1e63;&#x012b;t</em>, <em>ara&#x1e45;kta</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Prec. <em>rajy&#x0101;t</em>, <em>ra&#x1e45;k&#x1e63;&#x012b;&#x1e63;&#x1e6d;a</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; fut. <em>ra&#x1e45;kt&#x0101;</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>ra&#x1e45;k&#x1e63;yati</em>, <em>&#x25cb;te</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; inf. <em>ra&#x1e45;ktum</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; ind. p. <em>raktv&#x0101;</em> or <em>ra&#x1e45;ktv&#x0101;</em>), to be dyed or coloured, to redden, grow red, glow <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to be affected or moved, be excited or glad, be charmed or delighted by (instr.), be attracted by or enamoured of, fall in love with (loc.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>rajati</em>, <em>&#x25cb;te</em>), to go <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Naigh">Naigh.</a> ii, 14: Caus. <em>rajayati</em> (only <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a>) and <em>ra&#x00f1;jayati</em>, <em>&#x25cb;te</em> (aor. <em>ar&#x012b;rajat</em> or <em>arara&#x00f1;jat</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Pass. <em>rajyate</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; aor. <em>ara&#x00f1;ji</em> or <em>ar&#x0101;&#x00f1;ji</em>), to dye, colour, paint, redden, illuminate <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to rejoice, charm, gratify, conciliate <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MaitrUp">MaitrUp.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to worship <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Naigh">Naigh.</a> iii, 14 (<em>rajayati m&#x1e5b;g&#x0101;n</em> = <em>ramayati m&#x1e5b;g&#x0101;n</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 6-4, 24 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#V&#x0101;rtt">V&#x0101;rtt.</a> 3 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pat">Pat.</a>): Desid. <em>rira&#x1e45;k&#x1e63;ati</em>, <em>&#x25cb;te</em> Gr.: Intens. <em>r&#x0101;raj&#x012b;ti</em> (Gr. also <em>r&#x0101;rajyate</em> and <em>r&#x0101;ra&#x1e45;kti</em>), to be greatly excited, exult <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> ix, 5, 2 (others 'to shine bright'). [Cf. Gk. ?, 'to dye', ?, [861, 2] 'dyer.']</dd>

  <dt>&#x226b; rakta </dt>
  <dd><em>rakta</em> mf(<em>&#x0101;</em>)n. coloured, dyed, painted <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Br">Br.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#G&#x1e5b;&#x015a;rS">G&#x1e5b;&#x015a;rS.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> &amp;c.            <dd>&#x2022; N. of one of Skanda's attendants <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> </dd>

           <dd><em>rajan&#x012b;ya</em> w&#x1e5b;. for <em>mahan&#x012b;ya</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; rajayitr&#x012b; </dt>
           <dd><em>rajayitr&#x012b;&#x0341;</em> f. (fr. Caus.) a female painter or colourist <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VS">VS.</a></dd>

   <dt>&#x226b; rajas </dt>
   <dd><em>r&#x00e1;jas</em> n. 'coloured or dim space', the sphere of vapour or mist, region of clouds, atmosphere, air, firmament (in Veda one of the divisions of the world and distinguished from <em>div</em> or <em>svar</em>, 'the sphere of light', and <em>rocan&#x0101; diva&#x1e25;</em>, 'the ethereal spaces', which are beyond the <em>rajas</em>, as ether is beyond the air </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; often <em>rajas</em>, = the whole expanse of heaven or sky', divided into a lower and upper stratum, the <em>rajas uparam</em> or <em>p&#x0101;rthivam</em> and the <em>rajas uttamam</em> or <em>paramam</em> or <em>divyam</em> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; hence du. <em>rajas&#x012b;</em>, 'the lower and higher atmospheres' </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; sometimes also three and <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> i, 164, 6 even six such spheres are enumerated, hence pl. <em>raj&#x0101;&#x1e43;si</em>, 'the skies') <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#TS">TS.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VS">VS.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Br">Br.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; vapour, mist, clouds, gloom, dimness, darkness <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; impurity, dirt, dust, any small particle of matter <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c. (cf. <em>go-r&#x25cb;</em>) </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; the dust or pollen of flowers <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;lid">K&#x0101;lid.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; cultivated or ploughed land (as 'dusty' or 'dirty'), arable land, fields <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; the impurity, i.e. the menstrual discharge of a woman <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#G&#x1e5b;S">G&#x1e5b;S.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Su&#x015b;r">Su&#x015b;r.</a> &amp;c </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; the 'darkening' quality, passion, emotion, affection <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> &amp;c </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; (in phil.) the second of the three Gu&#x1e47;as or qualities (the other two being <em>sattva</em>, goodness, and <em>tamas</em>, darkness </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#cf">cf.</a> IW. 85 </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; <em>rajas</em> is sometimes identified with <em>tejas</em>, q.v </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; it is said to predominate in air, and to be active, urgent, and variable) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#S&#x0101;&#x1e43;khyak">S&#x0101;&#x1e43;khyak.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VarB&#x1e5b;S">VarB&#x1e5b;S.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Su&#x015b;r">Su&#x015b;r.</a> &amp;c </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; 'light' or 'day' or 'world' or 'water' <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Nir">Nir.</a> iv, 19 </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; a kind of plant (= <em>parpa&#x1e6d;a</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Bhpr">Bhpr.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; tin <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; autumn <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; sperm <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; safflower <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; m. N. of a &#x1e5a;ishi (son of Vasish&#x1e6d;ha) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VP">VP.</a> [Cf. Gk. ? ; Goth. <em>riqis</em>.] [863, 2]</dd>

   <dt>&#x22d9; rajastamaska </dt>
   <dd><em>&#x25cb;tamaska</em> mfn. (any one or any thing) under the influence of the two qualities <em>rajas</em> and <em>tamas</em> ( above) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; rajastamomaya </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;tamo-maya</em> mf(<em>&#x012b;</em>)n. made up or consisting of <em>r&#x25cb;</em> and <em>t&#x25cb;</em> (cf. prec.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#M&#x0101;rkP">M&#x0101;rkP.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; rajastas </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;tas</em> ind. from the dust, Praca&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; rajastur </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;t&#x00fa;r</em> mfn. penetrating the sky, hastening through the air <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; rajastoka </dt>

   <dt>ra&#x1e47; 1</dt>
   <dd><em>ra&#x1e47;</em> or <em>ran</em> (cf. &#x221a;<em>ram</em>), cl. 1. 4. P. <em>r&#x00e1;&#x1e47;ati</em>, <em>r&#x00e1;&#x1e47;yati</em> (2. du. <em>ra&#x1e47;y&#x00e1;tha&#x1e25;</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> i, 112, 18 </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; pf. [rAraNa] <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; aor. <em>ar&#x0101;&#x1e47;i&#x1e63;u&#x1e25;</em>, <em>ra&#x1e47;i&#x1e63;&#x1e6d;ana</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a>), to rejoice, be pleased, take pleasure in (loc., rarely acc.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; to gladden, delight, gratify <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a>: Caus. <em>ra&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;yati</em>, <em>&#x25cb;te</em>, to cheer, gladden, exhilarate with (instr. or loc.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; to be at ease, be pleased or satisfied with, delight in (loc.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#TS">TS.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a>: Intens.    <dd>&#x2022; Impv. <em>r&#x0101;randhi</em>, <em>r&#x0101;rantu</em>) = Caus. (as well in the trans. as in the intrans. meanings) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; ra&#x1e47;a 1</dt>
           <dd><em>r&#x00e1;&#x1e47;a</em> m. delight, pleasure, gladness, joy <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VS">VS.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (also n.) battle (as an object of delight), war, combat, fight, conflict <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; ra&#x1e47;akarman </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;karman</em> n. 'war-business', battle, fighting <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#M&#x0101;rkP">M&#x0101;rkP.</a></dd>

   <dt>ratha 1</dt>

           <dt>randh </dt>
           <dd><em>randh</em> &#x221a;<em>radh</em></dd>

   <dt>randhra </dt>
   <dd><em>r&#x00e1;ndhra</em> n. rarely m. (prob. fr. &#x221a;<em>rad</em>) a slit, split, opening, aperture, hole, chasm, fissure, cavity <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c. (nine openings are reckoned in the human body, <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#under">under.</a> <em>kha</em> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; and sometimes a tenth in the skull, as in the fontanel of an infant) </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; the vulva <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; a partic. part of a horse's head         <br>          <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VarB&#x1e5b;S">VarB&#x1e5b;S.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;i&#x015b;">&#x015a;i&#x015b;.</a> (cf. <em>upa-r&#x25cb;</em>) </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; a defect, fault, flaw, imperfection, weak part <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Y&#x0101;j&#x00f1;">Y&#x0101;j&#x00f1;.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c. (cf. <em>chidra</em>) </dd>

   <dd>&#x2022; the off spring of a Br&#x0101;hman and a Maitr&#x012b; <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a></dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; to play or sport, dally, have sexual intercourse with (instr. with or without <em>samam</em>, <em>saha</em>, <em>s&#x0101;kam</em> or <em>s&#x00e2;rdham</em>), ChUP. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to couple (said of deer) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 3-1, 26, V&#x0101;tt. 8 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pat">Pat.</a> (cf. Caus.) </dd>

           <dd><em>&#x25cb;muca</em> m. 'ray-emitting', the sun <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; ra&#x015b;mirasaprayoga </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;rasa-prayoga</em> m. N. of wk</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; ra&#x015b;mir&#x0101;ja </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;r&#x0101;ja</em> m. 'ray-lord', N. of a man <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Buddh">Buddh.</a> (cf. <em>ra&#x015b;mi-p&#x00e1;ti</em>)</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; ra&#x015b;mivat </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;v&#x00e1;t</em> mfn. = <em>-mat</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#TBr">TBr.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; ni. the sun <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>at&#x012b;</em>), f. a verse containing the word <em>ra&#x015b;mi</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;&#x1e6d;h">K&#x0101;&#x1e6d;h.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; &#x015b;atasahasra parip&#x016b;r&#x1e47;adhvaja </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x015b;ata-sahasra parip&#x016b;r&#x1e47;a-dhvaja</em> m. N. of a Buddha <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Buddh">Buddh.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; ra&#x015b;man </dt>
           <dd><em>ra&#x015b;man</em> m. = <em>ra&#x015b;m&#x00ed;</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; only in instr. <em>ra&#x015b;m&#x0101;&#x0341;</em> (cf. RV. vi, 67, 1) and ifc. (cf. <em>a-ra&#x015b;m&#x00e1;n</em> and <em>sth&#x0101;&#x0341;ra&#x015b;man</em>)</dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; ra&#x015b;min </dt>
           <dd><em>ra&#x015b;min</em> (ifc.) = <em>ra&#x015b;mi</em>, a rein, bridle <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; ra&#x015b;misa </dt>
           <dd><em>ra&#x015b;misa</em> m. N. of a D&#x0101;nava <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hariv">Hariv.</a> (v&#x1e37;. <em>rabhasa</em> and <em>nabhasa</em>)</dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; ra&#x015b;m&#x012b;vat </dt>
           <dd><em>ra&#x015b;m&#x012b;-v&#x00e1;t</em> mfn. = <em>ra&#x015b;mi-v&#x00e1;t</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VS">VS.</a></dd>

           <dt>ras 1</dt>
           <dd><em>ras</em> (cf. &#x221a;1. <em>r&#x0101;s</em>), cl. 1.P. (cf. Dh&#x0101;tup. xvii, 63) <em>rasati</em> (rarely &#x0100;. <em>&#x25cb;te</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; pf. <em>rar&#x0101;sa</em> <em>resu&#x1e25;</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; aor. [arAsIt] Gr </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; fut. <em>rasit&#x0101;</em>, <em>rasi&#x1e63;yati</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; inf. <em>rasitum</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a>), to roar, yell, cry, sound, reverberate <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to praise <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Naigh">Naigh.</a> iii, 14: Caus. <em>r&#x0101;sayati</em> (aor. <em>ar&#x012b;rasat</em>), Gr.: Desid. <em>rirasi&#x1e63;ati</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a>: Intens. <em>r&#x0101;rasyate</em> (or <em>r&#x0101;rasti</em>, Gr.), to cry out loudly, scream aloud <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Bha&#x1e6d;&#x1e6d;">Bha&#x1e6d;&#x1e6d;.</a></dd>

  <dt>&#x226b; rasana 1</dt>
  <dd><em>rasana</em> n. (for 2. p. 870, col. 3) the act of roaring or screaming or rumbling or thundering, any sound or noise <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VarB&#x1e5b;S">VarB&#x1e5b;S.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#B&#x0101;lar">B&#x0101;lar.</a> </dd>
  <dd>&#x2022; croaking (of frogs) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VarB&#x1e5b;S">VarB&#x1e5b;S.</a></dd>

   <dt>&#x226b; rasita 1</dt>
   <dd><em>rasita</em> mfn. (for 2. p. 871, col. 1) sounded, resounding, uttering inarticulate sounds <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;d">K&#x0101;d.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#G&#x012b;t">G&#x012b;t.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; n. a roar, scream, cry, noise, sound, thunder <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R&#x0101;jat">R&#x0101;jat.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; rasit&#x0101;&#x015b;in </dt>
           <dd><em>rasit&#x00e2;&#x015b;in</em> mfn. consuming or destroying by mere noise <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MW">MW.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; rasit&#x1e5b; 1</dt>
           <dd><em>rasit&#x1e5b;</em> mfn. (for 2. p. 871, col. 1) one who roars or bellows <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#S&#x0101;h">S&#x0101;h.</a></dd>

   <dt>ras 2</dt>
   <dd><em>ras</em> (rather Nom. fr. <em>rasa</em> below), cl. 10. P. (<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Dh&#x0101;tup">Dh&#x0101;tup.</a> xxxv. 77) <em>ras&#x00e1;yati</em> (rarely, &#x0100;. <em>&#x25cb;te</em> ep. also <em>rasati</em> and <em>rasyati</em>), to taste, relish <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Up">Up.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; to feel, perceive, be sensible of <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#S&#x0101;h">S&#x0101;h.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; to love <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Dh&#x0101;tup">Dh&#x0101;tup.</a>: Desid. <em>rirasayi&#x1e63;ati</em>, to desire to taste <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;i&#x015b;">&#x015a;i&#x015b;.</a></dd>

   <dt>&#x226b; rasa </dt>
   <dd><em>r&#x00e1;sa</em> m. (ifc. f. <em>&#x0101;</em>) the sap or juice of plants, Juice of fruit, any liquid or fluid, the best or finest or prime part of anything, essence, marrow <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; water, liquor, drink <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> &amp;c </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; juice of the sugar-cane, syrup <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Su&#x015b;r">Su&#x015b;r.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; any mixture, draught, elixir, potion <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; melted butter <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; (with or scil. <em>gav&#x0101;m</em>) milk <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; (with or scil. <em>vi&#x1e63;asya</em>) poison <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Da&#x015b;">Da&#x015b;.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R&#x0101;jat">R&#x0101;jat.</a> <font color="#FF0000" font size=-2><a name="p869-3"></a>[Page 869, Column 3]</font> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; nectar <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; soup, broth <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; a constituent fluid or essential juice of the body, serum, (esp.) the primary juice called chyle (formed from the food and changed by the bile into blood) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; mercury, quicksilver (sometimes regarded as a kind of quintessence of the human body, else where as the seminal fluid of &#x015a;iva) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Sarvad">Sarvad.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; semen virile <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> i, 105, 2 </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; myrrh <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; any mineral or metallic salt <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Cat">Cat.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; a metal or mineral in a state of fusion (cf. <em>upa-</em>, <em>mah&#x0101;-r&#x25cb;</em>) </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; gold <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; Vanguieria Spinosa <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; a species of amaranth <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; green onion <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; resin <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; = <em>am&#x1e5b;ta</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; taste, flavour (as the principal quality of fluids, of which there are 6 original kinds, viz. <em>madhura</em>, sweet </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; <em>amla</em>, sour </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; <em>lava&#x1e47;a</em>, salt </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; <em>ka&#x1e6d;uka</em>, pungent </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; <em>tikta</em>, bitter </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; and <em>ka&#x1e63;&#x0101;ya</em>, astringent </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; sometimes 63 varieties are distinguished, viz. beside the 6 original ones, 15 mixtures of 2, 20 of 3, 15 of 4, 6 of 5, and 1 of 6 flavours) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; N. of the number 'six' <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VarB&#x1e5b;S">VarB&#x1e5b;S.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;rutab">&#x015a;rutab.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; any object of taste, condiment, sauce, spice, seasoning <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> &amp;c </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; the tongue (as the organ of taste) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; taste or inclination or fondness for (loc. with or scil. <em>upari</em>, or comp.), love, affection, desire <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> &amp;c </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; charm pleasure, delight <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; (in rhet.) the taste or character of a work, the feeling or sentiment prevailing in it (from 8 to 10 Rasas are generally enumerated, viz. <em>&#x015b;&#x1e5b;&#x1e45;g&#x0101;ra</em>, love </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; <em>viira</em>, heroism </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; <em>b&#x012b;bhatsa</em>, disgust </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; <em>raudra</em>, anger or fury </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; <em>h&#x0101;sya</em>, mirth </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; <em>bhay&#x0101;naka</em>, terror </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; <em>karu&#x1e47;a</em>, pity </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; <em>adbhuta</em>, wonder </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x015b;&#x0101;nta</em>, tranquillity or contentment </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; <em>v&#x0101;tsalya</em>, paternal fondness </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; the last or last two are sometimes omitted </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#under">under.</a> <em>bh&#x0101;va</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Bhar">Bhar.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Da&#x015b;ar">Da&#x015b;ar.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;vy&#x00e2;d">K&#x0101;vy&#x00e2;d.</a> &amp;c </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; the prevailing sentiment in human character <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Uttarar">Uttarar.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R&#x0101;jat">R&#x0101;jat.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; (with Vaish&#x1e47;avas) disposition of the heart or mind, religious sentiment (there are 5 Rasas or Ratis forming the 5 degrees of <em>bhakti</em>, q.v., viz. <em>&#x015b;&#x0101;nti</em>, <em>d&#x0101;sya</em>, <em>s&#x0101;khya</em>, <em>v&#x0101;tsalya</em>, and <em>m&#x0101;dhurya</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#W">W.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; a kind of metre <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pi&#x1e45;g">Pi&#x1e45;g.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; N. of the sacred syllable, 'Om, 'cf. &#x015a;&#x0101;&#x1e45;khG&#x1e5b; </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; the son of a Nish&#x0101;da and a &#x015a;anak&#x012b; <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x0101;</em>), f. s.v</dd>

   <dd>&#x2022; possessing love and the other Rasas, impassioned, full of feeling, affected by emotions of love or jealousy &amp;c. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MW">MW.</a> <font color="#FF0000" font size=-2><a name="p870-2"></a>[Page 870, Column 2]</font> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; spirited, witty <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x012b;</em>), f. below </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; n. a tasteful style <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Bha&#x1e6d;&#x1e6d;">Bha&#x1e6d;&#x1e6d;.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Sch">Sch.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; <em>-tara</em> mfn. more savoury, more delightful <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Vikr">Vikr.</a> </dd>

   <dt>&#x226b; r&#x0101;k&#x0101; </dt>
   <dd><em>r&#x0101;k&#x0101;&#x0341;</em> f. (cf. U&#x1e47;. iii, 40) the goddess presiding over the actual day of full moon (or regarded as the Full Moon's consort </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; Anumati is supposed to preside over the previous day) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Jyot">Jyot.</a> (cf. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#IW">IW.</a> 158) </dd>

   <dt>r&#x0101;k&#x1e63;asa </dt>
   <dd><em>r&#x0101;k&#x1e63;asa</em> mf(<em>i</em>)n. (fr. <em>rak&#x1e63;as</em>) belonging to or like a Rakshas, demoniacal, infested by demons <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AitBr">AitBr.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c. (with <em>viv&#x0101;ha</em>, or <em>dharma</em> or <em>vidhi</em> m. 'one of the 8 forms of marriage', the violent seizure or rape of a girl after the defeat or destruction of her relatives, <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> iii, 33) </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; m. a Rakshas or demon in general, an evil or malignant demon (the R&#x0101;kshasas are sometimes regarded as produced from Brahm&#x0101;'s foot, sometimes with R&#x0101;va&#x1e47;a as descendants of Pulastya, elsewhere they are styled children of Khas&#x0101; or Su-rasa </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; according to some they are distinguishable into 3 classes, one being of a semi-divine benevolent nature and ranking with Yakshas &amp;c </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; another corresponding to Titans or relentless enemies of the gods </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; and a third answering more to nocturnal demons, imps, fiends, goblins, going about at night, haunting cemeteries, disturbing sacrifices and even devouring human beings </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; this last class is the one most commonly mentioned </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; their chief place of abode was La&#x1e45;k&#x0101; in Ceylon </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; in <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> v, 10, 17 &amp;c. they are fully described </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; cf. also cf. IW. 310 cf. RTL. 237) cf. Kau&#x015b;. cf. Up. &amp;c </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; a king of the Rakshas, g. <em>par&#x015b;v-&#x0101;di</em> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; (with Jainas) one of the 8 classes of Vyantaras cf. L </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; N. of the 30th Muh&#x016b;rta cf. L </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; of one of the astronomical cf. Yogas. cf. Col </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; of a minister of Nanda cf. Mudr </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; of a poet cf. Cat. (cf. below) </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; m. n. the 49th year in the Jupiter cycle of 6o years cf. VarB&#x1e5b;S </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x012b;</em>), f. a R&#x0101;kshas&#x012b; or female demon cf. MBh. cf. K&#x0101;v. cf. Kath&#x0101;s </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; the island of the R&#x0101;kshasas, i.e. La&#x1e45;k&#x0101; or Ceylon cf. Buddh </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; N. of a malignant spirit supposed to haunt the four corners of a house cf. VarB&#x1e5b;S </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; of a Yogin&#x012b; cf. Hcat </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; night cf. L </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; a kind of plant (= <em>ca&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;&#x0101;</em>) cf. L </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; a large tooth, tusk cf. L</dd>

           <dt>r&#x0101;kha&#x1e0d;&#x012b; </dt>
           <dd><em>r&#x0101;kha&#x1e0d;&#x012b;</em> (?), f. a partic.kind of ornament <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pa&#x00f1;cad">Pa&#x00f1;cad.</a></dd>

           <dt>r&#x0101;ga </dt>
           <dd><em>r&#x0101;ga</em> m. (fr. &#x221a;<em>ra&#x00f1;j</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; ifc. <em>&#x0101;</em>, or <em>&#x012b;</em>) the act of colouring or dyeing (cf. <em>m&#x016b;rdhaja-r&#x25cb;</em>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; colour, hue, tint, dye, (esp.) red colour, redness <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; inflammation <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Car">Car.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; any feeling or passion, (esp.) love, affection or sympathy for, vehement desire of, interest or joy or delight in (loc. or comp.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Up">Up.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; loveliness, beauty (esp. of voice or song) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;ak">&#x015a;ak.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pa&#x00f1;cat">Pa&#x00f1;cat.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a musical note, harmony, melody (in the later system a partic. musical mode or order of sound or formula </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Bharata enumerates 6, viz. <em>bhairava</em>, <em>kau&#x015b;ika</em>, <em>hindola</em>, <em>d&#x012b;paka</em>, <em>&#x015b;r&#x012b;-r&#x0101;ga</em>, and <em>megha</em>, each mode exciting some affection </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; other writers give other names </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; sometimes 7 or 26 R&#x0101;gas are mentioned </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; they are personified, and each of the 6 chief R&#x0101;gas is wedded to 5 or 6 consorts called R&#x0101;gi&#x1e47;&#x012b;s </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; their union gives rise to many other musical modes) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Bhar">Bhar.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Sa&#x1e43;g&#x012b;t">Sa&#x1e43;g&#x012b;t.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R&#x0101;jat">R&#x0101;jat.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pa&#x00f1;cat">Pa&#x00f1;cat.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; nasalization, Rpr&#x0101;t </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a partic. process in the preparation of quicksilver <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Sarvad">Sarvad.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; seasoning, condiment <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Car">Car.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a prince, king <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the sun <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the moon <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x0101;</em>), f. Eleusine Coracana (a sort of grain, commonly called R&#x0101;ggy, and much cultivated in the south of India) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of the second daughter of A&#x1e45;giras <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x012b;</em>), f. Eleusine Coracana <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; r&#x0101;gak&#x0101;&#x1e63;&#x1e6d;ha </dt>

           <dt>r&#x0101;j 1</dt>
           <dd><em>r&#x0101;j</em> (prob. originally two roots </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x221a;">&#x221a;.</a><em>raj</em> <em>ra&#x00f1;j</em>, <em>&#x1e5b;&#x00f1;j</em>), cl. 1. P. &#x0100;. ( <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Dh&#x0101;tup">Dh&#x0101;tup.</a> xix, 74) <em>r&#x0101;&#x0341;jati</em>, <em>&#x25cb;te</em> (Ved. also <em>r&#x0101;&#x1e63;&#x1e6d;i</em>, <em>r&#x0101;&#x1e6d;</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; pf. <em>rar&#x0101;ja</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>rar&#x0101;je</em> or <em>reje</em>, 2. sg. P. <em>rar&#x0101;jitha</em> or <em>rejitha</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; aor. <em>ar&#x0101;ji&#x1e63;u&#x1e25;</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>ar&#x0101;ji&#x1e63;&#x1e6d;a</em> Gr </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; fut. <em>r&#x0101;jit&#x0101;</em>, <em>r&#x0101;ji&#x1e63;yati</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; inf. <em>r&#x0101;j&#x00e1;se</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a>), to reign, be king or chief, rule over (gen.), direct, govern (acc.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to be illustrious or resplendent, shine, glitter <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to appear as or like (<em>iva</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kum">Kum.</a> vi, 49: Caus. <em>r&#x0101;jayati</em>, <em>&#x25cb;te</em> (aor. <em>arar&#x0101;jat</em>), to reign, rule <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to illuminate, make radiant (cf. <em>r&#x0101;jita</em>): Desid. <em>rir&#x0101;ji&#x1e63;ati</em>, <em>&#x25cb;te</em> Gr.: Intens. <em>r&#x0101;r&#x0101;jyate</em>, <em>r&#x0101;r&#x0101;&#x1e63;&#x1e6d;i</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> [For cognate words <br>          under <em>r&#x0101;jan</em>.]</dd>

           <dd><em>r&#x0101;dh&#x0101;</em> f. prosperity, success <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (also du.) N. of the 21st Nakshatra Vi&#x015b;&#x0101;kh&#x0101; (containing 4 stars in the form of a curve supposed to be <em>a</em>, <em>t</em>, <em>v</em>, Librae, and ? Scorpionis, cf. <em>nak&#x1e63;atra</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; lightning <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a partic. attitude in shooting (standing with the feet a span apart </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; cf. <em>-bhedhin</em>, <em>-vedhin</em>), Praca&#x1e47;&#x1e0d; </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Emblic Myrobolan <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Clytoria Ternatea <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of the foster-mother of Kar&#x1e47;a (q.v </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; she was the wife of Adhiratha, who was S&#x016b;ta or charioteer of king &#x015a;&#x016b;ra) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> (cf. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#IW">IW.</a> 377) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of a celebrated cowherdess or Gopi (beloved by K&#x1e5b;ish&#x1e47;a, and a principal personage in Jaya-deva's poem Gitagovinda </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; at a later period worshipped as a goddess, and occasionally regarded as an Avat&#x0101;ra of Lakshm&#x012b;, as K&#x1e5b;ish&#x1e47;a is of Vish&#x1e47;u </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; also identified with D&#x0101;ksh&#x0101;ya&#x1e47;&#x012b;) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#G&#x012b;t">G&#x012b;t.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pa&#x00f1;cat">Pa&#x00f1;cat.</a> &amp;c. (cf. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#IW">IW.</a> 332) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of a female slave <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Lalit">Lalit.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; r&#x0101;dh&#x0101;kavaca </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;kavaca</em> m. n. N. of wk</dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; delight, joy, pleasure <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MW">MW.</a></dd>

   <dt>r&#x0101;ma </dt>
   <dd><em>r&#x0101;ma</em> mf(<em>&#x0101;&#x0341;</em>)n. (prob. 'causing rest', and in most meanings fr. &#x221a;<em>ram</em>) dark, dark-coloured, black (cf. <em>r&#x0101;tri</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#T&#x0100;r">T&#x0100;r.</a> (<em>r&#x0101;ma&#x1e25; &#x015b;akuni&#x1e25;</em>. a black bird, crow <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;&#x1e6d;hG&#x1e5b;">K&#x0101;&#x1e6d;hG&#x1e5b;.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Vish&#x1e47;">Vish&#x1e47;.</a>) </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; white (?) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; pleasing, pleasant, charming, lovely, beautiful <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> &amp;c </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; m. a kind of deer <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Car">Car.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; a horse <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; a lover <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VarB&#x1e5b;S">VarB&#x1e5b;S.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; pleasure, joy, delight <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; N. of Varu&#x1e47;a. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; N. of various mythical personages (in Veda two R&#x0101;mas are mentioned with the patr. M&#x0101;rgaveya and Aupatasvini </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; another R&#x0101;mas with the patr. J&#x0101;madagnya [<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#below]">below].</a> is the supposed author of <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> x, 110 </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; in later times three R&#x0101;mas are celebrated, viz. 1. Para&#x015b;u-r&#x0101;ma <em>q.v.</em>, who forms the 6th Avat&#x0101;ra of Vish&#x1e47;u and is sometimes called J&#x0101;madagnya, as son of the sage Jamad-agni by Re&#x1e47;uk&#x0101;, and sometimes Bh&#x0101;rgava, as descended from Bh&#x1e5b;igu </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; 2. R&#x0101;ma-candra <em>see below</em> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; 3. Bala-r&#x0101;ma <em>q.v.</em>, 'the strong R&#x0101;ma', also called Hal&#x00e2;yudha and regarded as elder brother of K&#x1e5b;ish&#x1e47;a {cf. RTL. 112} accord. to Jainas a R&#x0101;ma is enumerated among the 9 white Balas </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; and in <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VP">VP.</a> a R&#x0101;mas is mentioned among the 7 &#x1e5a;ishis of the 8th Manv-antara) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c &amp;c. N. of a king of Malla-pura <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Cat">Cat.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; of a king of &#x015a;&#x1e5b;i&#x1e45;ga-vera and patron of N&#x0101;g&#x00ea;&#x015b;a <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; of various authors and teachers (also with <em>&#x0101;c&#x0101;rya</em>, <em>up&#x00e2;dhy&#x0101;ya</em>, <em>kavi</em>, <em>cakra-vartin</em>, <em>jyotir-vid</em>, <em>jyau-</em> <em>ti&#x1e63;aka</em>, <em>tarka-v&#x0101;g-&#x012b;&#x015b;a</em>, <em>d&#x012b;k&#x1e63;ita</em>, <em>daiva-j&#x00f1;a</em>, <em>pa&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;ita</em>, <em>bha&#x1e6d;&#x1e6d;a</em>, <em>bha&#x1e6d;&#x1e6d;&#x00e2;c&#x0101;rya</em>, <em>v&#x0101;japeyin</em>, <em>&#x015b;arman</em>, <em>&#x015b;&#x0101;strin</em>, <em>sa&#x1e43;yamin</em>, <em>s&#x016b;ri</em> &amp;c.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Cat">Cat.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; N. of the number 'three' (on account of the 3 R&#x0101;mas) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hcat">Hcat.</a> (<em>r&#x0101;masya i&#x1e63;u&#x1e25;</em>, a kind of cane = <em>r&#x0101;maka&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;a</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a>) </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; pl. N. of a people <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VP">VP.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x0101;&#x0341;</em>), f. a beautiful woman, any young and charming woman, mistress, wife, any woman <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Ka&#x1e6d;hUp">Ka&#x1e6d;hUp.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c. (for comp. p. 878) </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; a dark woman i.e. a woman of low origin <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#TS">TS.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#T&#x0100;r">T&#x0100;r.</a> </dd>

   <dt>&#x22d9; r&#x0101;macandra </dt>
   <dd><em>&#x25cb;candra</em> m. 'R&#x0101;mas-moon', N. of the principal R&#x0101;ma called D&#x0101;&#x015b;arathi, as son of Da&#x015b;a-ratha, and R&#x0101;ghava, as descended from Raghu (although the affix <em>candra</em> seems to connect him with the moon, he is not, like K&#x1e5b;ish&#x1e47;a and Bala-r&#x0101;ma, of the lunar but of the solar race of kings </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; he forms the 7th Avat&#x0101;ra of Vish&#x1e47;u and is the hero of the R&#x0101;m&#x0101;ya&#x1e47;a, who, to recover his faithful wife S&#x012b;t&#x0101;, advanced southwards, killed the demon R&#x0101;va&#x1e47;a and subjugated his followers the R&#x0101;kshasas, the poetical representatives of the barbarous aborigines of the south) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R&#x0101;matUp">R&#x0101;matUp.</a> (cf. IW. 330 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RTL">RTL.</a> 110) </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; N. of various kings and authors &amp;c. (also with <em>&#x0101;c&#x0101;rya</em>, <em>kavi</em>, <em>k&#x1e63;iti-pati</em>, <em>cakra-vartin</em>, <em>da&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;in</em>, <em>d&#x012b;k&#x1e63;&#x012b;ta</em>, <em>naimi&#x1e63;a-stha</em> or <em>v&#x0101;japeyin</em>, <em>ny&#x0101;ya-v&#x0101;g-&#x012b;&#x015b;a</em>, <em>parama-ha&#x1e43;sa</em>, <em>p&#x0101;&#x1e6d;haka</em>, <em>bha&#x1e6d;&#x1e6d;a</em>, <em>bha&#x1e6d;&#x1e6d;&#x00e2;c&#x0101;rya</em>, <em>bh&#x0101;rgava</em>, <em>bhi&#x1e63;aj</em>, <em>mi&#x015b;ra</em>, <em>yajvan</em>, <em>yat&#x012b;7&#x015b;vara</em>, <em>v&#x0101;cas-pati</em>, <em>&#x015b;&#x0101;strin</em>, <em>s&#x0101;rasvat&#x012b;</em>, <em>siddha</em> &amp;c.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Cat">Cat.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; <em>-karu&#x1e47;&#x0101;-s&#x0101;gara-candrik&#x0101;</em> f. <em>-kavaca</em> n. <em>-k&#x0101;vya</em> n. N. of wks </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; <em>-ga&#x1e47;&#x00ea;&#x015b;a</em> m. N. of an author <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Cat">Cat.</a> </dd>

   <dd>&#x2022; <em>-t&#x012b;rtha</em> m. (formerly, <em>m&#x0101;dhava &#x015b;&#x0101;strin</em>) N. of the successor of V&#x0101;g-i&#x015b;a-tirtha (of the Madhva school </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; he died in 1377) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Cat">Cat.</a> (cf. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RTL">RTL.</a> 130) </dd>

   <dd>&#x2022; (also with <em>&#x0101;c&#x0101;rya</em>, <em>yati</em>, <em>v&#x0101;cas-pati</em>, <em>sarasvat&#x012b;</em> &amp;c.) of various authors and other men <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Cat">Cat.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; <em>-t&#x012b;rtha</em> m. N. of a preceptor (also called <em>t&#x012b;rtha-sv&#x0101;min</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; <em>-r&#x0101;ya</em> and <em>-sv&#x0101;min</em> m. N. of two authors <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>

   <dt>&#x22d9; r&#x0101;m&#x0101;nuja </dt>
   <dd><em>r&#x0101;m&#x00e2;nuja</em> m. 'younger brother of R&#x0101;ma' (this title would be applicable to K&#x1e5b;ish&#x1e47;a as born after Bala-r&#x0101;ma of the same father) </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; N. of a celebrated Vaish&#x1e47;ava reformer (founder of a particular Vedantic school which taught the doctrine of <em>vi&#x015b;i&#x1e63;&#x1e6d;&#x00e2;dvaita</em> or qualified non-duality i.e. that the human spirit is separate and different from the one Supreme Spirit though dependent on it and ultimately to be united with it </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; he lived at K&#x0101;&#x00f1;c&#x012b;puram and &#x015a;r&#x012b;-ra&#x1e45;gam in the South of India, in the 12th century, and is believed by his followers to have been an incarnation of &#x015a;esha </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; he is also called R&#x0101;m&#x00e2;nuj&#x0101;c&#x0101;rya and Yati-r&#x0101;ja </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; n. or <em>jam matam</em>, R&#x0101;m&#x00e1;nuja's doctrine) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RTL">RTL.</a> 119, 448 &amp;c </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; (with <em>d&#x012b;kskita</em>) N. of another author <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Cat">Cat.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; <em>-guru parampar&#x0101;</em> f. <em>-grantha</em> m. <em>-camp&#x016b;</em> f. <em>-carita</em>, n. <em>-caritra</em> n. <em>-da&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;aka</em> m. or n. <em>-dar&#x015b;ana</em> n. N. of wks </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; m. N. of an author <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Cat">Cat.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; <em>-divyacaritra</em> n. <em>-bh&#x0101;&#x1e63;ya-g&#x0101;mbh&#x012b;rya</em> n. <em>-matakha&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;ana</em> n. <em>mata-dhva&#x1e43;sana</em> n. <em>-mauktika</em> n. <em>-va&#x1e43;&#x015b;&#x00e2;vali</em> f. <em>-vijaya</em>, m., <em>-&#x015b;ataka-&#x1e6d;&#x012b;k&#x0101;</em> f. <em>-siddh&#x00e2;nta-padavii</em> f. <em>-siddh&#x00e2;nta-vijaya</em> m. <em>-siddh&#x00e2;nta-sa&#x1e43;graha</em> m. <em>su-prabh&#x0101;ta</em>, n. <em>-stotra</em> n.            <dt>&#x226b; r&#x0101;m&#x0101;ya&#x1e47;a </dt>
           <dd><em>r&#x0101;m&#x0101;ya&#x1e47;a</em> mf(<em>&#x012b;</em>)n. relating to R&#x0101;ma (D&#x0101;&#x015b;arathi) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;&#x0101;r&#x1e45;gP">&#x015a;&#x0101;r&#x1e45;gP.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x012b;&#x0341;</em>), f. the female descendant of the Black One (<em>r&#x0101;ma</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> vi, 83, 3 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; n. (<em>ram&#x00e2;ya&#x1e47;a</em>) N. of V&#x0101;lm&#x012b;ki's celebrated poem, describing the 'goings' [<em>ayana</em>] of R&#x0101;ma and Sit&#x0101; (it contains about 24000 verses in 7 books called K&#x0101;&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;as, viz. 1. B&#x0101;la-k&#x0101;&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;a or &#x0100;di-k&#x1e6d;k&#x0101;&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;a </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 2. Ayodhy&#x0101;-k&#x1e6d;k&#x0101;&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;a </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 3. Ara&#x1e47;ya-k&#x1e6d;k&#x0101;&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;a </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 4. Kish kindhy&#x0101;-k&#x1e6d;k&#x0101;&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;a </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 5. Sundara-k&#x1e6d;k&#x0101;&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;a </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 6. Yuddha-k&#x1e6d;k&#x0101;&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;a </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 7. Uttara-k&#x1e6d;k&#x0101;&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;a </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; part of the 1st book and the 7th are thought to be comparatively modern additions </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the latter gives the history of R&#x0101;ma and S&#x012b;t&#x0101; after their re-union and installation as king and queen of Ayodhy&#x0101;, afterwards dramatized by Bhava-bh&#x016b;ti in the Uttara-r&#x0101;macaritra </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; R&#x0101;ma's character, as described in the R&#x0101;maya&#x1e47;a, is that of a perfect man, who bears suffering and self-denial with superhuman patience </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the author, V&#x0101;lm&#x012b;ki, was probably a Br&#x0101;hman connected with the royal family of Ayodhy&#x0101; </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; and although there are three recensions of the poem, all of them go back to a lost original recension, the ground work of which, contained in books 2-6, in spite of many amplifications and interpolations, may be traced back to one man, and does not like the Mah&#x0101;bh&#x0101;rata, represent the production of different epochs and minds) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hariv">Hariv.</a> &amp;c. (cf. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#IW">IW.</a> 335)</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; r&#x0101;m&#x0101;ya&#x1e47;akath&#x0101; </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;kath&#x0101;</em> f. 'the story of the R&#x0101;m&#x0101;ya&#x1e47;a', N. of an abridgment of the R&#x0101;m&#x0101;ya&#x1e47;a </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-pra&#x015b;na</em> m. N. of wk </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-s&#x0101;ra</em> m. or <em>-sara-ma&#x00f1;jar&#x012b;</em> f. N. of a poem based on the R&#x1e6d;R&#x0101;m&#x0101;ya&#x1e47;a, by Kshem&#x00ea;ndra (11th century)</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; r&#x0101;m&#x0101;ya&#x1e47;ak&#x0101;lanir&#x1e47;ayacandrik&#x0101; </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;k&#x0101;lanir&#x1e47;aya-candrik&#x0101;</em> f. N. of wk</dd>

   <dt>&#x22d9; r&#x0101;m&#x0101;ya&#x1e47;acamp&#x016b; </dt>

           <dt>r&#x0101;la </dt>
           <dd><em>r&#x0101;la</em> <em>r&#x0101;laka</em>, or <em>r&#x0101;li</em> m. the resin of &#x1e62;orea Robusta <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a></dd>

           <dt>r&#x0101;va </dt>
           <dd><em>r&#x0101;va</em> m. (&#x221a;1. <em>ru</em>) a cry, shriek, roar, yell, any sound or noise <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> &amp;c</dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; r&#x0101;va&#x1e47;a </dt>
           <dd><em>r&#x0101;va&#x1e47;a</em> mfn. (fr. Caus.) causing to cry (with gen. or ifc </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; only in this sense to explain the name of the famous R&#x0101;kshasa) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; m. N. of the ruler of La&#x1e45;k&#x0101; or Ceylon and the famous chief of the R&#x0101;kshasas or demons whose destruction by R&#x0101;macandra forms the subject of the R&#x0101;m&#x0101;ya&#x1e47;a (as son of Vi&#x015b;ravas he was younger brother of Kubera, but by a different mother, Ilavila being the mother of Kubera, and Ke&#x015b;in&#x012b; of the three other brothers R&#x0101;va&#x1e47;a Vibh&#x012b;sha&#x1e47;a, and Kumbha-kar&#x1e47;a </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; he is one of the worst of the many impersonations of evil common in Hind&#x016b; mythology </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; he has ten heads and twenty arms, symbolizing strength </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; this power was, as usual, acquired by self-inflicted austerities, which had obtained from Brahm&#x0101; a boon, in virtue of which R&#x0101;va&#x1e47;a was invulnerable by gods and divine beings of all kinds, though not by men or a god in human form </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; as Vish&#x1e47;u became incarnate in R&#x0101;ma-candra to destroy R&#x1e6d;R&#x0101;va&#x1e47;a, so the other gods produced innumerable monkeys, bears, and various semi-divine animals to do battle with the legions of demons, his subjects, under Khara, D&#x016b;sha&#x1e47;a, and his other generals) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hariv">Hariv.</a> &amp;c. (cf. IW. 353) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; patr. fr. <em>rava&#x1e47;a</em> g. <em>&#x015b;iv&#x00e2;di</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of a prince of Ka&#x015b;m&#x012b;ra <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R&#x0101;jat">R&#x0101;jat.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of various authors <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Cat">Cat.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x012b;</em>), f. (with <em>cikits&#x0101;</em>) N. of a medical wk </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; n. the act of screaming &amp;c. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MW">MW.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of a Muh&#x016b;rta <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Cat">Cat.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; r&#x0101;va&#x1e47;aga&#x1e45;g&#x0101; </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;ga&#x1e45;g&#x0101;</em> f. 'R&#x0101;va&#x1e47;a's Ganges', N. of a river in La&#x1e45;ka <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#G&#x0101;ru&#x1e0d;aP">G&#x0101;ru&#x1e0d;aP.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; r&#x0101;va&#x1e47;abhai&#x1e6d; </dt>

           <dt>&#x22d9; r&#x0101;va&#x1e47;avadha </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;vadha</em> m. 'killing of R&#x1e6d;R&#x0101;va&#x1e47;a', original N. of the Bha&#x1e6d;&#x1e6d;i-k&#x0101;vya</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; r&#x0101;va&#x1e47;avaha </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;vaha</em> m. (Pr&#x0101;k&#x1e5b;it = prec.) another N. of the Setu. bandha (q.v.)</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; r&#x0101;va&#x1e47;as&#x016b;dana </dt>

   <dt>r&#x0101;hitya </dt>
   <dd><em>r&#x0101;hitya</em> n. (fr. <em>rahita</em> ifc.) destituteness, non-possession, the being destitute of or free from or without <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#S&#x0101;h">S&#x0101;h.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Sarvad">Sarvad.</a></dd>

           <dt>r&#x0101;hila </dt>
           <dd><em>r&#x0101;hila</em> m. N. of a man <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R&#x0101;jat">R&#x0101;jat.</a></dd>

           <dt>r&#x0101;hu </dt>
           <dd><em>r&#x0101;h&#x00fa;</em> m. (fr. &#x221a;<em>rabh</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; cf. <em>graha</em> and &#x221a;<em>grah</em>) 'the Seizer', N. of a Daitya or demon who is supposed to seize the sun and moon and thus cause eclipses (he is fabled as a son of Vipra-citti and Si&#x1e43;hik&#x0101; and as having a dragon's tail </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; when the gods had churned the ocean for the Am&#x1e5b;ita or nectar of immortality, he disguised himself like one of them and drank a portion </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; but the Sun and Moon revealed the fraud to Vish&#x1e47;u, who cut off R&#x0101;hu's head, which thereupon became fixed in the stellar sphere, and having become immortal through drinking the Am&#x1e5b;ita, has ever since wreaked its vengeance on the Sun and Moon by occasionally swallowing them </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; while at the same time the tail of the demon became Ketu <em>q.v.</em> and gave birth to a numerous progeny of comets and fiery meteors </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; in astron. R&#x0101;hu is variously regarded as a dragon's head, as the ascending node of the moon <em>or point where the moon intersects the ecliptic in passing northwards</em>, as one of the planets [cf. <em>graha</em>], and as the regent of the south-west quarter [<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Laghuj">Laghuj.</a>] <font color="#FF0000" font size=-2><a name="p880-1"></a>[Page 880, Column 1]</font> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; among Buddhists many demons are called R&#x0101;hu) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; an eclipse or (rather) the moment of the beginning of an occultation or obscuration <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VarB&#x1e5b;S">VarB&#x1e5b;S.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; r&#x0101;hukanya </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;kanya</em> w&#x1e5b;. for <em>r&#x0101;h&#x016b;ga&#x1e47;ya</em>, q.v</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; r&#x0101;huk&#x0101;l&#x0101;val&#x012b; </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;k&#x0101;l&#x00e2;val&#x012b;</em> f. N. of wk</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; r&#x0101;hugata </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;gata</em> mfn. 'gone to R&#x0101;hu', darkened, eclipsed <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VarB&#x1e5b;S">VarB&#x1e5b;S.</a></dd>

           <dd><em>&#x25cb;gamya</em> mfn. liable to be obscured or eclipsed <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; r&#x0101;hugrasana </dt>

   <dd>&#x2022; p. <em>ririkv&#x00e1;s</em>, <em>riric&#x0101;n&#x00e1;</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>

   <dd>&#x2022; to separate or remove from (abl.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Bha&#x1e6d;&#x1e6d;">Bha&#x1e6d;&#x1e6d;.</a>: Pass. <em>ricy&#x00e1;te</em> (aor. <em>areci</em>), to be emptied &amp;c. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> &amp;c </dd>

   <dd>&#x2022; to be destroyed, perish <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a>: Caus. (or cl. 10 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Dh&#x0101;tup">Dh&#x0101;tup.</a> xxxiv, 10 </dd>

   <dd>&#x2022; Gk. [880, 2] ?, ? ; Lat. <em>linquo</em>, <em>licet</em> ; Lith. <em>likti</em> ; Goth. <em>leihwan</em> ; Angl. Sax. <em>le&#x00f3;n</em> ; Eng. <em>loan</em>, <em>lend</em> ; Germ. <em>l&#x00ee;han</em>, <em>leihen</em>.]</dd>

  <dt>&#x226b; rikta </dt>
  <dd><em>rikt&#x00e1;</em> mfn. (accord. to <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 6-1, 208, also <em>r&#x00ed;kta</em>) emptied, empty, void <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
  <dd>&#x2022; bared (as an arm) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Megh">Megh.</a> </dd>

  <dd>&#x2022; (ifc.) devoid or destitute of, free from, without <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> &amp;c </dd>
  <dd>&#x2022; m. (in augury) N. of one of the four wagtails which serve for omens <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VarB&#x1e5b;S">VarB&#x1e5b;S.</a> </dd>
  <dd>&#x2022; of a man <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pat">Pat.</a> </dd>
  <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x0101;</em>), f. (scil. <em>tithi</em>) N. of the 4th, 9th, or 14th day of the lunar fortnight <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VarB&#x1e5b;S">VarB&#x1e5b;S.</a> (cf. <em>rikt&#x00e2;rka</em>) </dd>
  <dd>&#x2022; n. an empty place, desert, wilderness, wood <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a></dd>

   <dt>&#x22d9; riktakumbha </dt>

           <dd>&#x2022; (only <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a>) to speak or boast (<em>kathane</em> or <em>katthane</em>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to blame </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to fight </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to give </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to hurt, kill (cf. &#x221a;<em>rimph</em>): Pass. <em>riphyate</em>, to be murmured or spoken in a guttural or burring manner (like the letter <em>r</em>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to have or take the pronunciation of the letter <em>r</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x0100;&#x015b;v&#x015a;r">&#x0100;&#x015b;v&#x015a;r.</a> (cf. <em>repha</em>)</dd>

   <dt>&#x226b; riphita </dt>
   <dd><em>riphit&#x00e1;</em> mfn. pronounced with a guttural roll (as the letter <em>r</em>), burred, rolled in the throat like <em>r</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VS">VS.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;&#x0101;&#x1e45;kh&#x015a;r">&#x015a;&#x0101;&#x1e45;kh&#x015a;r.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; repha </dt>
           <dd><em>repha</em> m. a burring guttural sound, the letter <em>r</em> (as so pronounced) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pr&#x0101;t">Pr&#x0101;t.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;rS">&#x015a;rS.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a word <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; passion, affection of the mind <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; mfn. low, vile, contemptible <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> (cf. <em>repa</em>)</dd>

(<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Dh&#x0101;tup">Dh&#x0101;tup.</a> xxvi, 29) <em>r&#x012b;&#x0341;yate</em> (<em>ri&#x1e47;&#x012b;te</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Br">Br.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#G&#x1e5b;&#x015a;rS">G&#x1e5b;&#x015a;rS.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; <em>riyati</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Dh&#x0101;tup">Dh&#x0101;tup.</a> xxviii, 111 </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; impf. <em>ari&#x1e47;van</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MaitrS">MaitrS.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; Gr.pf. <em>rir&#x0101;ya</em>, <em>rirye</em> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; aor. <em>arai&#x1e63;&#x012b;t</em>, <em>are&#x1e63;&#x1e6d;a</em> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; fut. <em>ret&#x0101;</em> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; <em>re&#x1e63;yati</em>, <em>&#x25cb;te</em> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; inf. <em>retum</em>), to release, set free, let go <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; to sever, detach from (abl.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; to yield, bestow <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; (&#x0100;.) to be shattered or dissolved, melt, become fluid, drop, flow <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a>: Caus. <em>repayati</em> (aor. <em>ar&#x012b;ripat</em>), Gr.: Desid. <em>rir&#x012b;&#x1e63;ati</em>, <em>&#x25cb;te</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a>: Intens, <em>rer&#x012b;yate</em>, <em>reray&#x012b;ti</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a></dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; natural propensity or disposition <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; style of speaking or writing, diction (three are usually enumerated, viz. <em>vaidarbh&#x012b;</em>, <em>gau&#x1e0d;&#x012b;</em>, <em>pa&#x00f1;c&#x0101;l&#x012b;</em>, to which a fourth is sometimes added, viz. <em>l&#x0101;&#x1e6d;ik&#x0101;</em>, and even a fifth and sixth, viz. <em>&#x0101;vantik&#x0101;</em> or <em>y&#x0101;vantik&#x0101;</em> and <em>m&#x0101;gadh&#x012b;</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#V&#x0101;m">V&#x0101;m.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;vy&#x00e2;d">K&#x0101;vy&#x00e2;d.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#S&#x0101;h">S&#x0101;h.</a> &amp;c </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; rust of iron <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; scoria or oxide formed on metals by exposure to heat and air <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a></dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; p. <em>r&#x00fa;vat</em>, <em>ravat</em>, <em>ravam&#x0101;&#x1e47;a</em>, <em>rav&#x0101;&#x1e47;a</em> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; to make any noise or sound, sing (as birds), hum (as bees) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>rauti</em>) to praise <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Naigh">Naigh.</a> iii, 14: Caus. <em>r&#x0101;vayati</em> (aor. <em>ar&#x016b;ruvat</em> with the sense of the Intens. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; or <em>ar&#x012b;ravat</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 7-4, 80 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Sch">Sch.</a>), to cause to bellow or roar, cause an uproar <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x0100;&#x015b;v&#x015a;r">&#x0100;&#x015b;v&#x015a;r.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c.: Desid. of Caus. <em>rir&#x0101;vayi&#x1e63;ati</em>, Gr.: Desid. <em>rur&#x016b;&#x1e63;ati</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a>: Intens. (Ved.) <em>r&#x00f3;raviiti</em> (p. <em>r&#x00f3;ruvat</em> and <em>r&#x00f3;ruv&#x0101;&#x1e47;a</em>) or (ep.) <em>ror&#x016b;yate</em>, <em>&#x25cb;ti</em> or (Gr.) <em>roroti</em>. to bellow or roar &amp;c. loudly, scream aloud, vociferate. [Cf. Gk. ? ; Lat. <em>raucus</em> ; [881, 3] Angl. Sax' <em>ry7n</em>.]</dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; pf. <em>ruroca</em>, <em>ruruc&#x00e9;</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Subj. <em>rurucanta</em> Pot. <em>rurucy&#x0101;s</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; p. <em>rurukv&#x00e1;s</em>, <em>ruruc&#x0101;n&#x00e1;</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; aor. <em>arucat</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R&#x0101;jat">R&#x0101;jat.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; <em>arukta</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#T&#x0100;r">T&#x0100;r.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; p. <em>ruc&#x0101;n&#x00e1;</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; aor. Pass. <em>aroci</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Prec. <em>ruc&#x012b;ya</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#T&#x0100;r">T&#x0100;r.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>roci&#x1e63;&#x012b;ya</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Br">Br.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>ruci&#x1e63;&#x012b;ya</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; fut. <em>rocit&#x0101;</em> Gr </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>roci&#x1e63;yate</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; inf. <em>rocitum</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>ruc&#x00e9;</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; ind. p. <em>rucitv&#x0101;</em> or <em>rocitv&#x0101;</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 1-2, 26), to shine, be bright or radiant or resplendent <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (only in pf. P.) to make bright or resplendent <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to be splendid or beautiful or good <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to be agreeable to, please (dat. or gen.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to be pleased with, like (acc.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to be desirous of, long for (dat.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hariv">Hariv.</a>: Caus. <em>roc&#x00e1;yati</em>, <em>&#x25cb;te</em> (aor. <em>&#x00e1;r&#x016b;rucat</em>, <em>&#x25cb;cata</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Pass. <em>rocyate</em>), to cause to shine <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to enlighten, illuminate, make bright <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to make pleasant or beautiful         <br>          <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AitBr">AitBr.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kum">Kum.</a> <font color="#FF0000" font size=-2><a name="p882-1"></a>[Page 882, Column 1]</font> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to cause any one (acc.) to long for anything (dat.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#G&#x012b;t">G&#x012b;t.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to find pleasure in, like, approve, deem anything right (acc. or inf.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to choose as (double acc.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to purpose, intend <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hariv">Hariv.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (Pass.) to be pleasant or agreeable to (dat.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a>: Desid. <em>ruruci&#x1e63;ate</em> or <em>ruroci&#x1e63;ate</em> Gr.: Intens. (only p. <em>r&#x00f3;ruc&#x0101;na</em>) to shine bright <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> [Cf. Gk. ?, ? ; [882, 1] <em>lux</em>, <em>luceo</em>, <em>luna</em>, <em>lumen</em> ; Goth. <em>liuhath</em>, <em>lauhmuni</em> ; Germ. <em>lioht</em>, <em>lieht</em>, <em>licht</em> ; Angl. Sax. <em>le&#x00f3;ht</em> ; Eng. <em>light</em>.]</dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; N. of a daughter of Bh&#x012b;shmaka and sister of Rukmin (betrothed by her father to &#x015a;i&#x015b;u-pala but a secret lover of K&#x1e5b;ish&#x1e47;i, who, assisted by Bala-r&#x0101;ma, carried her off after defeating her brother in battle </dd>

   <dt>&#x226b; rudra </dt>
   <dd><em>rudr&#x00e1;</em> mfn. (prob.) crying, howling, roaring, dreadful, terrific, terrible, horrible (applied to the A&#x015b;vins, Agni, Indra, Mitra, Varu&#x1e47;a, and the <em>sp&#x00e1;&#x015b;a&#x1e25;</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> (accord. to others 'red, shining, glittering', fr. a &#x221a;<em>rud</em> or <em>rudh</em> connected with <em>rudhira</em> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; others 'strong, having or bestowing strength or power', fr. a &#x221a;<em>rud</em> = <em>v&#x1e5b;d</em>, <em>v&#x1e5b;dh</em> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; native authorities give also the following meanings, 'driving away evil' </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; 'running about and roaring', fr. <em>ru</em> + <em>dra</em> = 2. <em>dru</em> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; 'praiseworthy, to be praised' </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; 'a praiser, worshipper' = <em>stot&#x1e5b;</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Naigh">Naigh.</a> iii, 16) </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; m. 'Roarer or Howler', N. of the god of tempests and father and ruler of the Rudras and Maruts (in the Veda he is closely connected with Indra and still more with Agni, the god of fire, which, as a destroying agent, rages and crackles like the roaring storm, and also with K&#x0101;la or Time the all-consumer, with whom he is afterwards identified </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; though generally represented as a destroying deity, whose terrible shafts bring death or disease on men and cattle, he has also the epithet <em>&#x015b;iva</em>, 'benevolent' or 'auspicious', and is even supposed to possess healing powers from his chasing away vapours and purifying the atmosphere </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; in the later mythology the word <em>&#x015b;iva</em>, which does not occur as a <em>name</em> in the Veda, was employed, first as an euphemistic epithet and then as a real name for Rudra, who lost his special connection with storms and developed into a form of the disintegrating and reintegrating principle </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; while a new class of beings, described as eleven <em>or thirty-three</em> in number, though still called Rudras, took the place of the original Rudras or Maruts: in <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VP">VP.</a> i, 7, Rudra is said to have sprung from Brahm&#x0101;'s forehead, and to have afterwards separated himself into a figure half male and half female, the former portion separating again into the 11 Rudras, hence these later Rudras are sometimes regarded as inferior manifestations of &#x015a;iva, and most of their names, which are variously given in the different Pur&#x0101;&#x1e47;as, are also names of &#x015a;iva <font color="#FF0000" font size=-2><a name="p883-2"></a>[Page 883, Column 2]</font> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; those of the <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#V&#x0101;yuP">V&#x0101;yuP.</a> are Aj&#x00e2;ikapad, Ahir-budhnya, Hara, Nir&#x1e5b;ita, &#x012a;&#x015b;vara, Bhuvana, A&#x1e45;g&#x0101;raka, Ardha-ketu, M&#x1e5b;ityu, Sarpa, Kap&#x0101;lin </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; accord. to others the Rudras are represented as children of Ka&#x015b;yapa and Surabhi or of Brahm&#x0101; and Surabhi or of Bh&#x016b;ta and Su-r&#x016b;p&#x0101; </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; accord. to <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VP">VP.</a> i, 8, Rudra is one of the 8 forms of &#x015a;iva </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; elsewhere he is reckoned among the Dik-p&#x0101;las as regent of the north-east quarter) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c. (cf. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RTL">RTL.</a> 75 &amp;c.) </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; N. of the number 'eleven' (from the 11 Rudras) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VarB&#x1e5b;S">VarB&#x1e5b;S.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; the eleventh <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Cat">Cat.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; (in astrol.) N. of the first Muh&#x016b;rta </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; (in music) of a kind of stringed instrument (cf. <em>rudr&#x012b;</em> and <em>rudra-vii&#x1e47;&#x0101;</em>) </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; of the letter <em>e</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Up">Up.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; of various men <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kath&#x0101;s">Kath&#x0101;s.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R&#x0101;jat">R&#x0101;jat.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; of various teachers and authors (also with <em>&#x0101;c&#x0101;rya</em>, <em>kavi</em>, <em>bha&#x1e6d;&#x1e6d;a</em>, <em>&#x015b;arman</em>, <em>s&#x016b;ri</em> &amp;c.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Cat">Cat.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; of a king <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Buddh">Buddh.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; du. (incorrect acc. to <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#V&#x0101;m">V&#x0101;m.</a> v, 2, 1) Rudra and Rudr&#x0101;&#x1e47;i (cf. also <em>bhav&#x0101;-r&#x25cb;</em> and <em>som&#x0101;-rudra</em>) </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; pl. the Rudras or sons of Rudra (sometimes identified with or distinguished from the Maruts who are 11 or 33 in number) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; an abbreviated N. for the texts or hymns addressed to Rudra <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#G&#x1e5b;&#x015a;rS">G&#x1e5b;&#x015a;rS.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Gaut">Gaut.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Vas">Vas.</a> (cf. <em>rudra-japa</em>) </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; of a people (v&#x1e37;. <em>pu&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;ra</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VP">VP.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x0101;</em>), f. a species of creeping plant <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; N. of a wife of Vasu-deva <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#V&#x0101;yuP">V&#x0101;yuP.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; of a daughter of Raudr&#x0101;&#x015b;va (v&#x1e37;. <em>bhadr&#x0101;</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VP">VP.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; pl. a hundred heatmaking suns' rays <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x012b;</em>), f. a kind of lute or guitar <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> (cf. m. and <em>rudra-vii&#x1e47;&#x0101;</em>)</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; rudra&#x1e5b;&#x1e45;mantradhy&#x0101;na </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;&#x1e5b;&#x1e45;-mantra-dhy&#x0101;na</em> n. N. of wk</dd>

   <dt>&#x22d9; rudrakala&#x015b;a </dt>

   <dd>&#x2022; <em>-sn&#x0101;na-vidhi</em> m. N. of wk</dd>

   <dt>rudh 1</dt>
   <dd><em>rudh</em> (cf. &#x221a;1. <em>ruh</em>, of which this seems to be only another form), cl. 1. P. <em>r&#x00f3;dhati</em>, to sprout, shoot, grow (only <em>r&#x00f3;dhati</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> viii, 43, 6 </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; and <em>vir&#x00f3;dhat</em>, i, 67, 9 </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; accord. to some also p. <em>rudhat</em>, i, 179, 4, in <em>nad&#x00e1;sya rudhat&#x00e1;&#x1e25; k&#x0101;&#x0341;ma&#x1e25;</em>, 'the desire of the growing reed' i.e. of the membrum virile </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; others, 'of the husband who keeps me away', fr. &#x221a;2. <em>rudh</em> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; cf. also <em>nada</em>)</dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; rodha </dt>

           <dd>&#x2022; m. growing, ascending, moving upwards (cf. next)</dd>

           <dd><em>rodhana</em> 2. <em>ava-</em> <em>ud-</em>, <em>-pra-r&#x25cb;</em></dd>

           <dt>rudh 2</dt>
           <dd><em>rudh</em> cl. 7. P. &#x0100;. (cf. Dh&#x0101;tup. xxix, 1) <em>ru&#x1e47;&#x00e1;ddhi</em>, <em>runddh&#x00e9;</em> (1. pl. <em>-rudhmas</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>rundhati</em>, <em>&#x25cb;te</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Br">Br.</a> &amp;c </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; <em>rurundhatu&#x1e25;</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> </dd>
